item.title: Return of the Obra Dinn - Narrated Modeling Mega Timelapse
item.description:
Creating characters, objects, and scenes for "Return of the Obra Dinn" from 2015-2018 *CONTAINS HOURS OF SPOILERS AND DRONING NARRATION*
This timelapse shows all my 3D-related work on Obra Dinn, from May 2015 (one year after development started), up to the game's initial release in October 2018. The timelapse 3D data was captured during development using custom tools, then re-cammed and narrated after release to produce this exhausting video.
https://youtu.be/qZFoBvJf8Ug is a tastefully stylized presentation of this same 3D timelapse data, minus the character modeling/painting and the commentary.
Homepage: https://obradinn.com Devlog: https://dukope.com/devlogs/obra-dinn
item.author: (Lucas Pope)

item.title: Matt Rosenberg (@nthmonkey) on Threads
item.description: My brother in law died in June. Heart attack. Four hours in the hospital and gone. And then the bills came. He’d let his insurance lapse two months prior. Bills were a few thousand here for the cardiologist, another few there for the ER docs, a bit for the radiologist. I helped my sister-in-law negotiate these down but they weren’t back breakers. Then the hospital bill came: $195k. This is a story about that.

item.title: .NET Libraries Are Beyond Saving
item.description:
Check out my courses on Dometrain: https://dometrain.com/courses/?ref=nick-chapsas&promo=youtube
Hello, everybody. I'm Nick, and in this video, I want to talk about the .NET Library ecosystem, focusing on open-source libraries specifically and talking about the different monetisation models that authors choose to adopt, as well as the idea that we can "save" open source projects by forking them.
Check out my workshops: https://dometrain.com/workshops/
Don't forget to comment, like and subscribe :)
Social Media: Follow me on GitHub: https://github.com/Elfocrash Follow me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/nickchapsas Connect on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/nick-chapsas
#csharp #dotnet
item.author: (Nick Chapsas)

item.title: Notes on where seat-based pricing is going - Arnon Shimoni
item.description: Everyone (mostly me) keeps saying seat pricing is dead, and some people are arguing with me online. I think that’s cool, but it’s because they don’t understand why it’s dying. For twenty years, SaaS revenue scaled with headcount.More humans = more seats.That logic held so long that we stopped questioning it. Then the humans disappeared. […]

item.title: Why We Need More Programmers, Not Fewer
item.description: TL/DR The conventional wisdom is that AI will reduce the demand for programmers. I manage engineering teams and program with LLMs every day, and I am seeing something different. Programmers who know how to work with LLMs can be 3-10x faster for specific tasks. Given that the size of our work backlog is only limited by our vision and ambition, these super-productive individuals will be more in demand, not less.

item.title: Dependencies, Inputs, Outputs: My Shortcut To Write Tests
item.description: I often struggle with writing unit tests. Sometimes, everything is clear before I even start coding: I can see the structure, and writing tests from the start feels natural. Those are good days.

item.title: Lessons learned from 2 years of operating a teensy-tiny news archive
item.description: I began running Andrew’s Selkouutiset Archive almost exactly two years ago, with a simple goal: Create a straightforward way for Finnish language learners to access the simple news broadcast by YYYY-MM-DD. It has basically accomplished that goal, with only a few tweaks here and there to keep everything running. Earlier in the series: Lessons learned from 6 months of operating a teensy-tiny news archive. I stand by those points, and have some more to add here at the 24-month mark.

item.title: What I want from a National Data Library – Andreas Varotsis
item.description: I built a tool to fix my local police engagement problem in an hour of café coding. But that was only possible because of a fading public data API from years ago…let’s revive the open data dream with the National Data Library!

item.title: Generalized Consensus: Governing Rules | Multigres
item.description: As we solve the problem of durability, we will realize that there is a simple set of governing rules that we will be applying repetitively. We will develop these as we progress in our design. However, we will share their entirety upfront.

item.title: Avoid 2:00 and 3:00 am cron jobs! | End Point Dev
item.description: A word to the wise: Do not set any cron jobs for 2:00 am or 3:00 am on Sunday morning! Or to be safe, on other mornings besides Sunday as well, since jobs originally set to run on some particular day may eventually be changed to run on another day, or every day.

item.title: live public transport routing
item.description: We've all used a public transit router to find a quick route from A to B, such as Google Maps or CityMapper, but how do they actually work? In this post I will discuss how I tried to build my own public transport routing system for London that supports buses, tubes and trains.
